metahuman structures and algorithms ultimately lead to enslavement. They consume, imprison, and
destroy the citizen who resigns of the ability to influence the future and preserve agency over his or
her time.
     However, the most famous critique of the Leviathan appears in the 1690 Lock’s ‘Second Treatise of
civil government’ (Ch VII/93) (Lock, n.d.). John Locke described absolute sovereignty as a catastrophic
lack of judgment and governance, rather than a solution. To describe the horrors of such automated
and mechanical power, he uses the allegory of a society avoiding attacks by wild cats that lets the lion
rule and devour everyone: ‘To ask how you may be guarded from harm or injury, on that side where
the strongest hand is to do it, is presently the voice of faction and rebellion: as if when men quitting
the state of nature entered into society, they agreed that all of them, but one, should be under the
restraint of laws, but that he should still retain all the liberty of the state of nature, increased with
power and made licentious by impunity. This is to think, that men are so foolish, that they take care to

relationship between might and right, or between sovereignty, power, and law as experiences of
agency, ontology and cosmology, and time as Chronos and Kairos. Although ‘absolute authority’ in
Hobbes is a necessary condition for the law to exist, Lock criticizes it as a dangerous precedent that
makes the law impossible. Automated decision making that is hardcoded without human oversight is
an heir to this ideal of absolute authority and mechanical or automated sovereignty. It confronts us
with the same problem of unchecked and uncontrolled power that someone ultimately designs without
letting the rest participate in it except by resigning on their agency and sovereignty. How to then engage
with the authority of the code and automated control of the new algorithmic sovereigns (technological
platforms as Lockean lions) and contest their power? How to involve citizens in the formation of the
algorithmic Leviathan as a lion without letting the algorithmic beasts devour the autonomy while
promising to protect them from small dangers (wild cats)?

advantage of citizen data, freedom, and agency. It is an artificial system (contract, mechanism) that has
absolute authority over the citizens who trade their sovereignty and natural rights for security. In his
analysis of the Leviathan, Schmitt explicitly described this as the emergence of the ideal of a ‘state as a
mechanism’ and a ‘manmade product’ (Schmitt, 2008) that is neither holy nor ideal, but efficient:
‘Considering the Leviathan as a great command mechanism of just or unjust states would ultimately be
the same as ‘discrimination’ between just or unjust machine.’ (Ibid.)

unity that enabled all later forms of industrial state to use new technologies as tools of sovereignty. The
idea of a state as a technical apparatus, or what we call algorithmic governance, was born with the
metaphor of the Leviathan: ‘The intrinsic logic of the ‘state’ of a man-made artificial product does not
culminate in a person but in a machine. Not the representation by a person, but the factual, current
accomplishment of genuine protection is what the state is all about. Representation is nothing if it is
not tutela praesens. However, this can only be attained by an effectively functioning

governance. It is the original prototype of absolute and arbitrary power that nothing can resist because
everyone will be willing to submit to it: ‘[T]hat state was created not only an essential intellectual or

Exploratory Sandbox Supporting Tactical and participatory automation
     Is there any alternative to the absolute victory of the modern state as an algorithmic machine, a
cybernetic warship that performs sovereignty through its structure and code while claiming to
guarantee survival rather than justice or any value? How to rethink algorithmic sovereignty beyond the
images of the Leviathan and its shadow, the Wicker Man? Instead of insisting on

of the Leviathan and its shadow, the Wicker Man? Instead of insisting on one or the other
mythical figures, we propose multiplying them through sandboxes. In these zoos for ‘dangerous’
algorithms, participants (stakeholders) can experiment with the gradual process of ‘domestication’ of
algorithms. Simulation of decision-making processes in the sandbox combines smart contracts with
existing policy tools for regulation. It balances algorithmic ‘wilderness’ with domestication through
regulations.
     This vision of governance over prototypes in the sandboxes engages and supports rather than

domesticate them. The exploratory and public sandboxes for algorithmic services offer a model on how
to make the automation process more ‘representational’ and participatory, so it is clear at each step
what we sacrifice and outsource to the code.

4.3 Conclusions
     Prototypes in society mediate the different expectations and experiences of time and agency over
the future. On the one hand, they support the open-ended exploration and flourishing of human
agency. On the other hand, they promise innovation as control over the future and governance.
Examples of ancient clocks, Renaissance visions of scientific instruments that bring light (experimenta
lucifera), or infrastructures for automation close the future to predetermined goals of progress and
theological restoration. As Renaissance cosmoscopes, living instruments, and examples of the folly of
empiricism, including present open science hardware, prototypes open the future to human agency
and action with no guarantees. Unlike the teleological expectations of progress and restoration,
forgotten and marginal prototyping practices imagine radical transformation on multiple micro, meso
and macro levels.
     In previous chapters we have contrasted the prototypes that reinforce the myth of automation with
the possibility of autotelic prototypes that support the experience of time as Kairos (Chapters 2 and 3),
opportunity for transformation, and plural future(s). The examples of open science hardware in Chapter
3, along with the living instruments and cosmoscopes of the past (Chapters 2.3 and 2.4), demonstrate
the personal and social agency as this capacity to transform

461.text:
and 2.4), demonstrate
the personal and social agency as this capacity to transform the human condition and society. Instead
of obeying the insights into time as Chronos with its teleology of predetermined goals and futures, the
experience of time as Kairos is about the agency over the future and time.


     The community-driven and DIY (do it yourself) instruments (Chapter 3) revive the practices of
artisans and natural philosophers described by critics, such as Francis Bacon, as an anarchistic folly of
empiricism with fruitful experiments serving no one (experimenta fructifera in Chapter 2.3). Such open-
ended, forgotten, and marginal Renaissance projects, including the tinkering of modern artisans,
hackers, geeks, and makers define prototyping as a matter of participation and empowerment. Instead
of supporting the myth and ideal of automation in governance represented by the figures of the
Leviathan and Wicker Man, such prototyping is an opportunity for agency, vision, and experiments
beyond any universal solution and absolute rule. In this sense, prototyping defines a need for
democratizing future-making and realizing that time is Kairos, a public resource and infrastructure for
commons preserving the opportunity for our agency.
     The marginal and forgotten examples of prototypes supportive of open future make science,
technology, and society personal and political rather than a cosmological or ontological project.

Prototyping that supports Kairos as a personal and social agency over time in Chapters 2 and 3 served
as a model for the exploratory governance of emerging infrastructures over sandboxes in Chapter 4.
Instead of depending on MIT and TED homo faber interventions that always meet predefined targets,
the sandboxes support citizens and tinkers as homo ludens. Citizens design and prototype together to
generate new and temporary visions of a community and their future. They create tools to engage,
understand, tinker, customize, and demystify the power behind every scientific and technological
disruption.
     Science and technology as mundane, accessible, and everyday practice resist the myth of
automation as an ideal for governance. Makers, geeks, and tinkerers modeled after the ambiguous
figure of Thales and homo ludens, cherish their free time as an opportunity to explore and question
(even dissent) both governance and technology. Their prototypes are cosmoscopes, and living
instruments use scientific insights for social experiments carefully balancing knowledge and power
(Chapter 2.3). In this sense, they embody the hopes of Walter Benjamin, who in his ‘One-way street
essay’ described the connection of metaphysics, cosmology and technology as crucial to defining
personal and social agency in the new century: ‘Nothing so distinguishes ancient from modern man as
the former’s submission to a cosmic experience of which the latter is scarcely aware.’

463.text:
to a cosmic experience of which the latter is scarcely aware.’ (Benjamin, 2009)
     Benjamin was ambiguous about the reduction of cosmology to new technologies (optical apparati)
with their metaphysical automation leading to absolute political unity and mechanical reproduction. He
described these experiences as types of intoxication we know from rituals that create a sense of
community and politics based on transcendence (aura): ‘Intoxication, of course, is the sole experience
in which we grasp the utterly immediate and the utterly remote, and never the one without the other.
However, this means that communicating ecstatically with the cosmos is something man can only do
communally. ‘ (Ibid.) To neutralize the intoxication, he advocated a more reflective use of cosmology
and metaphysics in science and technology. He showed that cosmology or what we call here the
experience of time as Chronos does not liberate but brings the horrors of WWI and homo faber: ‘new
and unprecedented marriage with cosmic powers…. Technology betrayed mankind and turned the
marriage bed into a sea of blood. ‘ (Ibid.)
     Science and technology in Benjamin, however, are not only a matter of control over nature, history,
or future, but also a search for new relations with the universe, including the formation of new
collectives (he uses the common reference in the 20s and 30s of the ‘proletariat’). It is the search for
more authentic technology, community, and cosmology over tools

It is the search for
more authentic technology, community, and cosmology over tools in parallel that supports the personal
and communal experience of time and agency. We describe such tools as prototypes for governance
and propose liminal and exploratory sandboxes as environments, where this could be experiences. To
rethink the role of humanity in various forces and scales mobilized over the new tools and knowledge,


we need to prototype and communicate with the external world ‘ecstatically’, playfully and creatively.
It means embracing the tools of science and technology as probes into new collectives and networks,
while remaining skeptical about their use as solutions promising automation while perpetuating the
status quo.
     The ‘new and unprecedented marriage with cosmic powers’ (Ibid.) through technologies and
prototypes supports unimaginable control in terms of military and industrial misuses as well as the
playfulness that we see in hackerspaces or alternative history of instrument making. The control brings
the possibility of a total war, which another of the 20th century authors brilliantly described in a story
about the ‘Vietnam project’ (Coetzee, 1996). J M Coetzee reflected upon the uncanny relation of
technology with cosmology in his description of a paranoia that closes the future to one grandiose
project.

Behind every military technology, Coetzee identifies the cosmic ambitions of Earth’s ‘celestial sons’
(humans and their rockets, etc.) who want to destroy old myths and leave ‘mother Earth’ to mate with

and heaven? We live no longer by tilling the earth but by devouring her and her waste products. We

of the sky-god with his parthonegene daughter-queen. If the play has been poor, it is because we have
stumbled about the stage asleep, not knowing the meaning of our acts. Now I bring their meaning to
light in that blinding moment of ascending meta-historical consciousness in which we begin to shape
our own myths (Ibid..).

     The proposal for exploratory and public sandboxes as ‘trading zones’ was inspired by Peter Galison’s
metaphor describing how innovation, discovery, and regulation occur in the case of particle physics in
the 20th century (Galison, 1997). Galison was able to show how successful exchanges between various
stakeholders (scientists, but also policymakers and businesses) depended on the importance of
preserving their identity and diversity, event potential conflicts. Instead of finding a single unified
theory, practice, value or institution, innovation (and we claim also regulation) depends on the plurality
and dissent as experiences of Kairos. Neither the absolute power of the code nor some predefined
values should define the common algorithmic and automated future, but the ability to ‘trade’ with
groups and stakeholders we do not understand or agree on: ‘But here we can learn from the
anthropologists who regularly study unlike cultures that do interact, most notably by trade. Two groups
can agree on rules of exchange even if they ascribe utterly different significance to the objects being
exchanged; they may even disagree on the meaning of the exchange process itself. Nonetheless, the
trading partners can hammer out a local coordination despite vast global differences. In an even more
sophisticated way, cultures in interaction

sophisticated way, cultures in interaction frequently establish contact languages, systems of discourse
that can vary from the most function-specific jargons, through semispecific pidgins, to full-fledged
creoles rich enough to support activities as complex as poetry and metalinguistic reflection.’ (Ibid..) In
the exploratory sandboxes and trading zones, we can create a contact language between programming
and natural language, code and regulation, current institutions and future infrastructures, present

can collaboratively design new Leviathans that enable tactical and situated decisions with the main goal

me, Dr. Stefanie Wuschitz and Dr. Cindy Lin, captured the full extent of these interactions over science,
technology, and community.Their dictionary of words related to tinkering, technology, and science
even defines these activities as a form of collective and creative "hanging out" or "gotong-royong," an
informal communal work that includes tools, new ideas, and infrastructures.
      Science and technology as an experience of hanging out and gathering work because of the flow
rather than the telos (goal) of various projects and explorations. These gatherings lead to hacktivist
fantasies of independent infrastructure and capacity building via open science hardware, but this is not
their main goal. Prototyping in Yogyakarta is an ongoing collective experimentation with an open future
rather than a ’social action' or means for a startup pitch. Tinkering with science and technology,
discussing and weighing the social and political issues and playing with artistic ideas happens
simultaneously. It serves individuals and collectives

473.text:
artistic ideas happens
simultaneously. It serves individuals and collectives to engage over new technologies and ideas, rather
than predefined goals of social or technological progress or abstract calls to bridge different divides.
      Surrounded by friends who became my global family, I experienced prototypes as explorations that
remain open-ended, even transgressive, and easily incorporate art, pop culture, myths. The experience
of friendship, tinkering, exploration, and literal cooking in various maker and hacker communities


around the world led me to the thesis that prototyping is a form of "doing" philosophy, creating
community or governing society that I described as exploratory sandbox. It is a unique experience of
time that makes you realize the importance of our agency over the future.
     The art and citizen science activities initiated by HONF (House of Natural Fiber) and later by
Lifepatch (Citizens Initiative for Arts, Science and Technology), as well as interactions with various
collectives around the world, changed my view of how individuals and communities adopt and integrate
new technologies and knowledge into their lives and culture. I was inspired by the work of fellow
researchers and academics from the Gadjah Mada University, such as Professor Irfan D. Prijambada, for
whom community outreach was always part of research, or Prof. Mohan Dutta and his Center for
Culture-Centered Approach to Research and Evaluation (CARE)

474.text:
Center for
Culture-Centered Approach to Research and Evaluation (CARE) to see that my ideas are part of a larger
movement for true empowerments. These individuals and initiatives inspired me to imagine a future of
science, technology, and society that supports personal and social action beyond any teleology of
progress, exaggerated expectations of startup culture, or final and idealized goals.
     Prototyping in informal networks of geeks, makers, and hackers around the world rarely results in
a finished product. It always remains a work on a community, fostering personal relationships and
visions of the world. The flow and processes of prototyping bridge cultural and geopolitical divisions
and emphasize the unique experience of time as Kairos, leaving the future open to new engagements
rather than obsessing over outcomes and products. As Yair Reshef, my "partner in (prototyping) crime"
and founder of Tel Aviv Makerspace, once summed up in a 2014 chat: ‘I tell ppl that in hackerspaces
we don’t *start* anything. we are here to fail. gracefully if possible. completed projects tend to become
a showoff. people always look for the product. a goal embodied in an object. It should be effortless.
effortless technology.’
     It was during the first Asia-Pacific DIYbio & Bioart Meeting ‘Democratizing the Laboratory” in 2011
that I realized that the pace of our technological and scientific progress does

475.text:
in 2011
that I realized that the pace of our technological and scientific progress does not necessarily need to
exceed our moral and social maturity. Hackerspace and makerspace demonstrate the opposite:
Tinkering with science and technology was always a way to define our values, negotiate visions, and
shape a future that meets our needs and desires. The geeks, artists, designers, and academics who
participated in these gatherings combined in unexpected ways their scientific, artistic, and social
practices, values, and institutions. In Yogyakarta, universities were always connected to local
communities, villages, artists’ organizations, and various other collectives, where they also prototyped
to strengthen these relationships.
     The rich cultural traditions as well as the environmental and economic challenges created the
conditions for unique and radical visions that Prof. Mrázek pointed at in that casual remark, which made
no sense to me back in 2008. We do not have to visit Silicon Valley, NASA, or a Mars colony to
experience future communities that are resilient to extreme conditions by embracing new
technologies. Groups of artists, scientists, and farmers around Yogyakarta have been using prototypes
to study climate change around the Merapi volcano in Java at least since 2012, when the HONF
Foundation launched its Micro/Macro Nation project. They connected prototypes of ethanol reactors
that ferment waste to farm aquaponics systems and collected data from these experiments for an
artistic performance.

476.text:
aquaponics systems and collected data from these experiments for an
artistic performance. They even hacked an Indonesian government satellite to get the environmental
data they needed to predict the effects of climate change, setting a precedent in governance with open
data for future scenarios. None of this was part of any official ideology or project but a work of an
opportunity that expresses the longing for a community and future that is open, radical, and
experimental.


     Prototyping was always at the heart of these activities that explored the agency over the future. It
combined research with community activism, hacktivism, artistic sensibility and visions that made me
question the dichotomies between theory and practice, community and tools (infrastructure), science,
technology, and art. Whether as Hackteria's hacked webcams with a stage for a microscope made by
Indonesian artisans, or gel electrophoresis chamber made from IKEA Tupperware for modernist food
dyes, or the optical density and turbidity sensors made from "tick-tock" boxes, these tools combined
esthetic, critical, and philosophical engagements similar to the ones I recognized in the origins of
science in the 16th century.
     While working and living between Indonesia, Switzerland, and Singapore, I engaged with
instruments, kits, and projects that served not only scientific education and research, but also as VJing
and DJing and even science (geek) diplomacy. These tools created an "imagined community" or
transglobal and interdisciplinary

477.text:
diplomacy. These tools created an "imagined community" or
transglobal and interdisciplinary collaborations that defied all geopolitical and other orders. The
prototypes fostered creative appropriations of scientific protocols, open source technologies, but also
unique collaborations between universities, arts organizations, and local communities, between
science and indigenous knowledge, design, and craft.
     I never expected that Yogyakarta would play such an important role in my identity as a scientist,
designer, and philosopher, but Professor Mrázek predicted it. This DIY capital of the world inspired me
to rethink my own cultural and disciplinary boundaries, even ideas about who family and friendships
are. I still feel part of my nomadic family, which I formed while prototyping around the world with
friends from all continents, cultures, and boundaries. Rudolf Mrázek's prophecy is true because it
expresses a provocation that is relevant to all of us. Indonesia and other places outside established
cultural and technological centers, just as forgotten practices in older periods in our own culture, bring
new and unexpected connections between social, cultural, and technological practices.

498.text: The Myth of Automation from Sundial to Blockchain: Governance over Rituals, Machines, and Prototypes is a discussion of the fantasy of automation and control over time and the future. It examines the metaphysical, political, and material conditions under which governance becomes a matter of automation and algorithms. It combines metaphysical questions of time and agency with political questions of power to discuss the relationship between science, technology, and society as a problem of prototyping. It focuses on the use of the future and time as conditions of automation and explores how prototypes can democratize power over the future and time. It also examines the potential of prototypes to open the future to public participation and define political and technological representation as a matter of practice.

499.text: This book explores the alternatives to governance as automation, proposing an experimental sandbox that combines prototyping with governance to support personal and social action and agency over the future. It examines the dynamic of ‘imagination and calculation’ as a question of action and structure (knowledge) and focuses on how to democratize future making and prototyping. It uses genealogy to identify and defuse the arbitrary exercise of power in promissory infrastructures and new instruments, and rethinks the role of prototyping in governance. It proposes exploratory sandboxes that extend the practices identified in the forgotten history of instrument making and observed in the liminal spaces. These sandboxes increase participation and redefine representation, and support direct public participation and agency. They enable citizens to define their stake in the future and prevent excesses of algorithmic rule and automation. The book defines time as a medium of action and politics rather than a matter of ontology or cosmology, and emphasizes prototyping as an opportunity to reconcile personal and social goals with external constraints. It proposes sandboxes as a model for tactical decisions about the future, emphasizing everyday practices that abstract, appropriate, buy, cheat, choose, colonize, commodify, compress, conquer, control, create, de-contextual

500.text: This book explores the genealogy of automation and its implications for design and policy making. It identifies forgotten anxieties and fantasies of governance as automation and questions control over the future and time. Prototyping in public and exploratory sandboxes demystifies magical control over the future and time, and exposes the myth of automation beyond every infrastructure that demands personal and collective sacrifices. It encourages agonistic, plural, and open futures, and supports engagement with institutions and social and political processes. The proposal for exploratory sandboxes supports personal and collaborative experiences on future making that emphasize personal and social agency over time. It guards the open future dependent on the participation of citizens as stakeholders, and safeguards society from the arbitrary excesses of every new prototype, technology, and ‘demonic’ infrastructure. The classic Greek dichotomy of Chronos and Kairos is used to summarize the tensions between structure and agency as a problem of legitimacy in algorithmic governance. Chronos reduces individual life and social processes to predesigned systems that ignore commitment to a personal or collective project that expresses Kairos. Kairos is expressed in tactical interventions, political and personal projects that use prototyping to explore both governance and technology. It is synonymous with taking responsibility for the future, risking, even failing, but

501.text: This article examines the concept of automated governance, which reduces political decision-making to a matter of control over the future and time, and transforms social and political processes into algorithms. It discusses the idea of governance as a well-designed, predefined, and automated system, which is at the core of Hobbes’s social contract theory. It also looks at how algorithms are not mysterious entities at the end of history, but are the result of human action and knowledge, hybrids of Chronos and Kairos. The article proposes prototyping governance as a way to reclaim control over the future and time, and to resist the undemocratic and arbitrary rule of designers and their patrons. It suggests that citizens should be participants and stakeholders in their future, rather than mere users of future infrastructures.

502.text: This article examines the origins of the myth of automation, which can be traced back to the 6th century B.C.E. and the anecdotes about Thales of Miletus. It connects Thales' knowledge of astronomical cycles and time as Chronos to his free time, which is interpreted as Kairos. Kairos is time synonymous with freedom to act and agency to discover, innovate, and transform. The anecdotes capture an essential attribute of a free Athenian citizen – his agency over time that uses cosmological insights to impact society. Thales' prediction and fall capture the experience of time as Kairos, an opportunity for success and failure, or discovery and leisure. The power of new tools and instruments over the future conceals the source of that control – time as Kairos. Instruments and tools that take advantage of the insights into Chronos often reduce the freedom of action and agency of the user.

503.text: Thales' insights into Chronos, the cosmological 'Big Data' of cycles, patterns, and data, enabled him to create a tool for monopoly and wealth. In Plato's version of the anecdote, Thales uses his knowledge of Chronos to mock the values of merchants and aristocrats, challenging the illusions of their social and economic importance. His insights into the 'whole' of time and space, the holon (ὅλον), give him the autonomy to think and act like a god with respect to the future. Rather than an immediate advantage, his future is about control, care, and critique. Thales' experience of time as Kairos, free time to explore, discover, and intervene into technology and society, reinforces personal and social power over the future.

504.text: In Plato and Aristotle's anecdotes about Thales, the future is discussed as a matter of control and care. Plato's version of the story contrasts the merely 'advantageous' future with the radical idea of a future as care and concern (μέλλω). This implies lawmaking and action, and is synonymous with the idea of the 'whole'. Thales' control over the future also implies nomos (νόμος), lawmaking and governance, that are trying to achieve something permanent and binding even 'after time'. Thales' knowledge mocks the values of merchants and aristocrats in Athens as ignorance and incorrect application of the knowledge of cosmology. Future as matter of care then implies lawmaking and action, and is described as expertise, connoisseurship, and artistic creation. Thales' anecdotes define the origins of Western philosophy as the problem of future and time control through science and technology. Thales exercises his epistemic and political autonomy as knowledge (of Chronos) that controls the future and time in two ways. He uses his free time as an opportunity (Kairos) to develop a monopoly tool that controls the future through a prediction (Chronos). At the same time, he insists on the

505.text: The term 'parasite' originally referred to someone seeking free dinner, and has since been used to describe an organism that leeches on another. This metaphor has been used to describe the social and economic underclass, which faces similar challenges with its loss of agency in an automated world. The victims of automation do not form any politics or future together, and their only option is to be tolerated as guests on tables and platforms. The clock deprived the parasites of control over their own metabolism and needs, and today's parasites are dehumanized data patterns of algorithmic systems. The reign of false scarcity, urgency, and hidden slavery present in every governance machine since the clock has led to the reduction of citizens and political subjects to a surplus, precarious, obsolete, and transgressive parasites of the algorithmic platforms and tables. To prevent the rule of the governance machine and Chronos, we must capture the genealogy of this resignation upon agency and the possibility of personal and social action. The transformation of instruments into governance machines marks the birth of algorithmic governance, which reduces politics to ontology and cosmology and defines governance as a matter of prototyping new infrastructures.

506.text: The anecdotes of Thales' contraption, Plautus' curse of the sundial, and the lamentations of the hungry parasites all demonstrate the possibility of a monopoly as a reason to criticize and challenge the status quo in society. The sundial and clepsydra, two instruments of timekeeping, were responsible for the automation of governance and the deprivation of citizens of their freedom, agency, and even leisure. The sundial created false scarcity, while the clepsydra introduced false urgency and slavery, reducing all public life to a matter of survival. The rule of Chronos and the worship of the Sun or other phenomena of Chronos with new rituals and instruments further undermined the experience of Kairos as an opportunity, chance, and complexity. The clepsydra also served as an early example of a tool that supports biases intrinsic in today's aggregation of data serving predictive analytics. The prewritten speeches for clepsydra laid the foundation for today's ‘prewritten’ smart contracts that automate not only the decision-making process, but also the execution of the ‘judgment’, leaving no room for doubt, error or ambiguity. The worship of Chronos leads to monopoly contraption, automatic (in)justice, and even censorship

507.text: In this passage, Plato (via Socrates and Thales) discusses the idea of time as Kairos, or the possibility of acting and changing the future, and rejects the clepsydra and explores more radical uses of Chronos. Thales uses his cosmological knowledge as a power to challenge existing stereotypes and injustices in society and inspire citizens to rethink and redefine the future. Algorithms reduce political processes (Kairos) to logical conclusions described as chains of events (Chronos) that enforce an arbitrary epistemic certainty beyond human control. This leads to the enslavement of citizens and the reduction of decision-making and agency to the inevitable but arbitrarily constructed Chronos. Renaissance artisans and open science hardware developers continue in the tradition of Thales’ ambiguous ‘contraption’ and knowledge, demonstrating the importance of personal and social action through prototyping that supports Kairos in technology and governance. Algorithms claim universal patterns in natural and social systems, but their use in politics is neither universal nor just, it is arbitrary and without a clear mandate. To resist control of time and the future, we should strive to be Plato connoisseurs and artists who indulge in the uniqueness of their experience rather than promises of universal control.

508.text: The dichotomy of Chronos and Kairos is an ambiguous one, expressing a tension between natural systems and political projects. Chronos is the essence of the myth of automation and algorithmic rule, transforming governance into a technological ritual and dividing society into patrons and hungry parasites. Chronos defines the quantification of time that abolishes history and the ‘complexity of human action’ (Kairos). Prototyping restores Kairos in governance as a matter of agency against the rule of Chronos as the certainty and predictability of patterns and cycles. Myths and rituals are precursors of automation that show how the certainty and stability of the solar cycle or similar patterns in nature serve as a preferred model for governance for the elites. Instruments as governance machines repeat the narrative about an infrastructure for the public good, using “objective” measurements and algorithms to nonetheless serve the private interests of the patrons. To save democratic governance, we must preserve the importance of Kairos, time as an opportunity for action and decision-making.

509.text:
The power of patrons over parasites is represented by the 'unbendable' pointer of the Ethereum machine, like the sundial pointed in the Alciphrone passage. This power was made visible after the 2016 attack on DAO, which revealed that all clocks, computers, networks, and infrastructures, including blockchain ledgers, exaggerate the point of public good resistant to ‘bending’ and hacking. Instruments and prototypes often obscure their arbitrary origins and impose themselves as infrastructures that represent the public good. Time as Chronos, controlling dinners, transactions, and other social interactions via clocks and decentralized ledgers, obscures the actions of Kairos, design and governance decisions responsible for the new infrastructures.

The design of the clocks determines the ledger synchronization no matter how democratized the new infrastructure claims to be. To save agency over time and the future, we need to preserve the ‘momentum’ of Kairos and make technology more ‘democratic’ and open to interventions. Renaissance artisans and today's geeks, hackers, and makers revive the ambiguity of Thales' project, which offers a model for public engagement with science, technology, and governance.

Prototypes of Renaissance instruments affirmed

510.text: Francis Bacon's vision of the future as a project of Instauratio (restoration) uses instruments without mentioning their designers, such as Cornelius Drebbel. Bacon accused artisans like Drebbel of being mere tricksters who manipulate the wealthy patrons and the public without advancing the one true goal of governance and technology. Renaissance artisans, alchemists, and mechanical philosophers, such as Drebbel, explore future(s) beyond the teleological promises of Instauratio. Their playful engagements with prototypes of new instruments are open-ended and equally concerned with transformation and Kairos in science, technology, and society (governance). Bacon's instruments supported restoration (Instauratio) and teleology of progress, while Drebbel's artisan instruments explored ambiguous and open-ended objectives closer to Agamben's paradigms. Bacon's new institution (the Academy of Science) secures the power of patrons as representatives of God's plan over the future and over time. Bacon literally speaks of the ‘time's masculine birth’ (temporis partus masculus) which is synonymous with automation. Through disruptive prototypes and knowledge representing this birth, humanity is promised efficiency, plan, and control over the future. The new patrons are world transformers

511.text: Prototyping as a material and conceptual engagement with science, technology, and governance has served various pragmatic, didactic, and even emancipatory purposes throughout history. Giorgio Agamben's discussion of paradigm, model, and exempla captures knowledge and practice that combines ontology, cosmology, and politics without supporting any teleological notion of final ends. Paradigms emphasize knowledge as much as participation and define meaning as something that has to remain open to iteration. They reject any finality of something predetermined or expected at the end of time and create new concepts, institutions, and values without insisting on their universality. Prototypes as paradigms explore the relationship between science, technology, and society without insisting on any teleology of desiderata or Instauratio. They are precedents that make new orders, objects, classes, or sets visible and intelligible as a ‘singularity that, showing itself as such, produces a new ontological context’. Agamben's paradigms and regulae capture the importance of prototyping for restoring the time as Kairos in governance and technology. They link reflection to action and define governance as an open-ended process, a performance instead of a repetition serving some ideal knowledge, insight (Chron

512.text: Prototyping is a practice that liberates the future and time for personal and social action beyond patrons’ control of the parasites. It is a care for what might exist and the expression of agency. Futures worth of trouble is a concept borrowed from Foucault to describe a type of curiosity about a future without a definitive goal and agenda, such as progress. Agamben's paradigms and examples, Foucault’s curiosity explains prototyping as a practice that liberates the future and time for personal and social action beyond patrons’ control of the parasites. Prototyping for governance means exploring the uncertain futures ‘worth of trouble’ that express individual and collective aspirations that are neither final nor controlled by any patron or God. Cornelius Drebbel's prototypes are examples of Agamben’s paradigms that explore the future as that which might exist, or which is worth the troubles, against the ideas of necessary, predetermined and close telos. They are curiosity-driven explorations of the universe and our place in it, empowering everyone to become an artisan with direct and authentic relationship with the universe and the future.

513.text: Robert Drebbel's Archimedean sphere is a clock that bridges the divide between vitalist and mechanical notions of life and machine, or chance and design. It uses chemical processes to power a mechanical clock, creating a precedent that reconciles the idea of time as Kairos, an act of creation, with Chronos, a control based on a mechanical contraption. Drebbel's prototypes explore alternatives to automation and algorithmic rule closer to dreams and performances, and express Foucault’s ‘care’ for what could exist. They define prototyping as experiments with possible futures without restoring or automating anything, and capture a ‘forgotten fantasy’ of a single living machine that encapsulates, proves, and effortlessly conveys universal knowledge of nature. They oppose the teleological ideals of Bacon’s progress, and instead support personal and social actions as Kairos experiences without the goal of restoring human power over nature.

514.text: This summary explores the contrast between Bacon's academy of science as Salomon's House and the forgotten alternatives of artisan projects by Drebbel, Bornitz, and Leibniz. Bacon's academy serves the project of Instauratio and fulfills God's promise to humanity, while Drebbel's folly of empiricism and Bornitz's transgender body politics use instruments and prototypes to perform the future as open to engagement and radical visions. Bacon detests the serendipitous experimenta fructifera that do not follow any commitment to Instauration, and instead of controlling the public, the artisan prototypes only amuse and engage. Polyani's 'community of explorers' follows the predefined goals that remain absolute, and Comenius's living tree of knowledge opposes the myth of automation and the pre-defined goals of restoration. Artisan cosmoscopes and living instruments define true knowledge as part of a 'living' universe, and their prototypes make the future unpredictable and open. Bacon's academy and the later ideals of science, such as Polanyi's 'community of explorers', reduce governance to Chronos and close the future for the parasites.

515.text: Technocratic ideas of governance, including algorithmic governance, are all successors of Bacon's Instauratio, which seeks to reduce governance to matters of ontological and religious justification. Artisan projects in the Renaissance period, such as those of Bornitz, Drebbel, and Comenius, emphasize agency, opportunity, and Kairos in governance, science, and technology. Johann Becher and Cornelius Drebbel explicitly claim that this transformation includes ‘inner’ and personal work. Leibniz's ‘Odd Thought Concerning a New Sort of Exhibition (or rather an Academy of Sciences)’ in 1675 is a prophetic vision of the type of organizations we are starting to witness in the present. It is a liminal environment closer to the hackerspaces discussed in Sections 3.1, 3.2 and 3.3 where prototypes generate new ecologies of interests and influences. Leibniz's Academy was a precedent that offered a model for open and democratized future-making, using bottom-up engagements and prototypes common in today's incubators, community labs, and hackerspaces. It emphasizes hybrid and experimental relationships between science, technology, business, and even art, and all engagements depend on events and performances that emphasize Kairos

516.text: Leibniz's academy is an institution that explores the relationships between nature and society without teleology and hierarchy. It emphasizes Kairos, opportunity, agency, and the transience of encounters. Events and performances at the academy stimulate public interest in science and technology and attract investment to support the experiments. It is a hybrid and liminal space for new networks, where new relationships are constantly being fostered. It combines Chronos with Kairos to support imaginative and open futures of science, technology, and governance. Prototyping creates new instruments and infrastructures that close the future to one goal, but also expresses agency, time, and future as open and ‘autotelic’ activity. It supports Kairos in governance over various liminal environments and explores a future as a monad that mirrors the various ontological and political engagements and commitments.

517.text: This article examines the role of prototyping in technology and governance, and how it has evolved from the early anecdotes of clocks and science instruments in the Renaissance period. It discusses the automation myth, which reduces politics to cosmology and ontology, and imposes the rule of rituals, instruments, and infrastructures on society. To save politics and time as Kairos, the right time and moment for action and decision, the article proposes to rethink the role of prototyping in technology and governance. It discusses the examples of hackerspaces and makerspaces that are restoring the forgotten Renaissance practices of instrument making, and how they emphasize the importance of curiosity, dreams, and ideas of the ‘future anterior’. It also discusses the need for democratization of science and technology, and how open science hardware instruments and the open hardware innovation ecosystem in Shenzhen can help preserve the experience of time as Kairos.

518.text: Prototyping is an important political action as well as a technological one, as demonstrated by self-governance experiments. It is a way to preserve agency and Kairos in governance, emphasizing participation and empowerment. Barbara Cassin's two concepts of time in ancient Greek philosophy inspired the view of prototyping as the expression of Kairos in technology and governance. The city is an autotelic prototype, performing governance as a social and individual practice without reducing it to cosmos, Chronos, or pre-defined soul. To save agency and Kairos, autotelic prototypes are needed to democratize future-making and oppose the regressive teleological ideals of progress. The age of prototypes and demos is challenging our understanding of the public good and common interest, as they can be used to impose arbitrary power over public life, imagination, personal, and social agency. To save history, politics, and agency, we need prototypes that empower citizens to engage with science and technology as a matter of politics. Hackerspaces and makerspaces are a way to resist the reduction of the future to one project and to create tools without a clear agenda.

519.text:
Hackerspaces and makerspaces are creative, yet often failed explorations of the skills of hackers. They form communities around tools and open-source projects that are expressions of resistance and exploration of different (mis)uses. These prototypes are autotelic and participatory, supporting artists, philosophers, and other unexpected ‘users’. They shape a global culture of alternative networks of knowledge production and sharing that serve plural and sometimes conflicting needs and goals. Prototypes in hackerspaces provoke fellow citizens instead of solving world problems, and are leisure activities that remind us of the original purpose of Thales’ monopoly over olive presses. They question the effects of intrusive and sinister technologies and test the comfort levels around them. 

Prototyping for governance is an insistence on time as Kairos, which includes experiments and iteration on politics as much as science and technology. Ethnographic research has mapped these networks and identified an informal geek diplomacy that combines private and public, even political and geopolitical agendas. Examples of projects include transforming a common Indonesian mobile food truck into a scientific laboratory, connecting science to everyday life practice, and exploring the media archeology of etching. All of these projects support the development of science infrastructure for the Global South and challenge the view that discovery and

520.text: Prototyping for governance is a practice that bridges the social, epistemic, and political divides crucial for any social transformation. It supports the experience of time as Kairos, an opportunity for change and action that resist the reduction of governance to technology, algorithms, or other forms of Chronos. Examples of Open Science Hardware (OSH) instruments, such as Hackteria's OpenDrop electrowetting platform, the reverse osmosis filtration system and DIY spectrometry in the ‘Open Source Estrogen’ project, and the microsatellites for space exploration in Nepal, demonstrate how these instruments can be used to explore science, politics, and art. The Open Science Hardware manifesto, formulated during the first meeting of OSH geeks, makers, and citizen scientists in CERN in 2016, outlines the purpose and values of these open and ambiguous uses of science instruments. Prototyping for governance enables citizens to gain agency and disperse the asymmetries of power, actively defining their future by connecting prototyping with governance.

521.text: This article discusses the use of prototypes as a means of personal and social agency, as described by Hannah Arendt's active life. It focuses on the use of prototypes to bridge disciplinary divides and transform society, as well as the ambiguity of prototyping creating monopolies or exploring the open future. It also looks at how DIY makers, hackers, and present artisans use prototypes to interact, define, and perform what living together means in the changing sociotechnical milieu. It examines the hybrid and small-scale projects of DIY science, which share the values of invisible colleges of the 17th century, and the convergences between social, political, scientific, and technical processes. It also looks at the emancipatory and exploratory prototypes of Hackteria microfluidics, such as OpenDrop electrowetting, which capture hybrid and artisanal engagements with Kairos in governance and technology. It concludes by discussing how participants in workshops use their time as Kairos to influence science, technology, and governance.

522.text: The GaudiLabs YouTube channel documented strange uses ranging from speculations on space research in microgravity to ‘pay-per-play’ entertainment formats of engagement with laboratory automatization over the so-called ‘smart contracts’ and other blockchain speculations. The OpenDrop is a tool developed by Urs Gaudenz to enable citizens to directly experience and manipulate some aspect of nature and discuss with their peers the ethical dilemmas, political goals, or some other aspects of such action. Hackteria instruments are prototypes that do not replicate the goals of professional (‘big’) science with cheaper tools, but instead bring science to new places outside professional laboratories to test new relations between science, technology and society. These repositories emphasize the scientific interests, which are partially emancipatory and try to improve science reproducibility and access to tools, while also including political actions and aesthetic pleasures. Prototypes enable unique collaborations and interactions that support the ideal of open future and freedom without guarantees, and they become a medium of political vita activa or leisurely otium outside of labor and work. Examples of projects such as Timothy Olmer's Hypodiabetic blog and the Open Insulin Project by Counter Culture Labs, as well as the Open Source Est

523.text: Olmer's Open Insulin Project showed the impossibility of creating a functional tool for real-time insulin application without parallel changes in policy, regulations, and the patent system. This project revealed the limits of governance and values in society, and served as a critique of current models of medicine production. The Open Estrogen Project, led by biohackers and artists Marry Magic and Byron Rich, explored the ambiguous status of estrogen in society, our bodies, and nature. Through workshops and experiments, the project enabled citizens to have direct experience with their responsibility and stakes in the scientific, political, and social controversies surrounding estrogen. The project also explored the contradictions of estrogen in the public imagination, species evolution, and nature, and left the ideal future of estrogen open to interventions and Kairos of political, social, and individual actions. The prototypes in these projects supported communities seeking to explore the new relations between nature, culture, technology, and politics, and enabled more people to do science. They also defined new forms of public participation and material engagements with science, where the pursuit of knowledge supports the deliberation and creative explorations of an open future.

524.text: Studies acknowledge the role of historical, social, political and cultural circumstances in the development of various instruments. Science artisans in the past and present connect their instruments with various agendas in society, bringing science closer to public life. Prototypes of science instruments define various (failed) attempts to demarcate and emancipate science from religion, scholastic philosophy, politics, and also from crafts. The complex connections between the instruments and their various political, social and religious agendas are central topics in many sociology of science and laboratory studies. The revival of instrument making in the hackerspaces and makerspaces challenges the idea of public defined by Joseph Wright’s classic 18th century painting ‘An Experiment on a Bird in the Air Pump’. The present air pumps are part of everyday, mundane activities depicted on various websites and social media supporting tinkering and DIY (Do-It-Yourself) and DIWO (Do-It-With-Others) practices. From the civic and independent monitoring of water and air quality to sound and VJing performances, artistic and conceptual explorations, and also entrepreneurial and educational uses, open science hardware shows alternatives to academic and professional research. The plural, hybrid, and often ambiguous (mis)uses of instruments show science as

525.text: DIY air-pumps and prototypes are a form of sociotechnical initiation that bridge divides between science, politics, and design. They are "boundary objects" that negotiate conflicting goals and perform "social-political work" along scientific research. DIYbio scholarship embraces the ability of these prototypes to bridge divides and transform society. They are "convivial and materialized tools" that support cross-platform, digital and analogue, material and immaterial production of knowledge. They are "promisory and evocative objects" that flexibly link material experimentation with discourse, deliberation and reflection. They are "punk, unruly, domestic and unfinished" and emphasize processes and engagements above results. They allow citizens to imagine and explore different futures for science and society. They are "symptoms of a crisis" but also support governance as "transitory associations of people, technologies, and natural entities". They reveal their origins in everyday life through tinkering practices and invite people to take part in their development. They are ambiguous and contested to enable political and personal freedom of connecting science with various personal and social goals. They bridge the present divides between amateur (DIY) and professional science, but also libertarian and emancipatory uses.

526.text: Prototypes of open science hardware instruments are being used to bridge divides between amateur and professional science, as well as libertarian and communitarian values. These instruments are being used to explore health, environment, and normative ideals, as well as metaphysical, aesthetic, and exploratory values of blockchain technologies. They are being used to create a community that deals with risks and uncertainties on individual and communal levels, and to create a public sphere free from productive concerns and biological necessities of life. These prototypes are being used to create a balance between new knowledge and infrastructure with personal and social agency, and to create a public sphere free from productive concerns and biological necessities of life. They are also being used to create a future open to imaginative projects that combine science, technology, and society, and to reject the monopolization of the future by industries and institutions.

527.text: Prototypes are tools of civic action that challenge the conventional dichotomies of contemplative and practical reason and the related concepts of labor, work, action, and leisure. They enable citizens to express personal and public visions for the future through material practices. Examples of open science hardware, citizen laboratories, and hackerspaces illustrate how prototypes foster transnational networks and projects described as ‘geek diplomacy’. This concept of governance over prototypes restates the radical materialism of Pierre Bayle, Denis Diderot, or Baron d’Holbach and insists on pragmatic and open-ended engagements against the teleological agendas of restoration and progress. It is an agonistic ideal of future making as a matter of Kairos that serves open, even conflicting, political ends that are crucial for preserving the agency, plurality, and freedom of the political life.

528.text: This paper explores the concept of Kairos in governance and technology, which is an open future that is open to change and transformation without any final goals. It uses the example of the Special Economic Zone (SEZ) in Shenzhen, China, which was a mythical place of innovation and hacker dreams between 2012 and 2015. It was a relatively neutral zone, where everyone could come, prototype and scale production by engaging with various local and global networks, actors, and visions. The network of geeks involved in this liminal prototyping communitas included the first hardware accelerator, HAXL8R, and the open hardware hacker and developer Bunnie Huang. Seeed Studio emerged in 2008 as a global, open hardware facilitation company targeting EU and US markets. The liminal prototypes in Shenzhen broke the common divisions between the developed and developing countries or other common dichotomies of innovation and scaling, designing and manufacturing. They embodied Zilsel’s thesis on instrumentation making and prototyping as a process that breaks social divisions and transforms society. The example of Safecast, a radiation monitoring kit prototyped in 2011 by an international community around the Tokyo hackerspace, demonstrates the hybrid and liminal possibilities of an emerging public engaged in technology and governance. It offers a counter example

529.text: Shenzhen, China is a unique geopolitical site for experiments with open hardware communitas prior to 2015. These experiments combined various ideologies and interests that spawned the ambiguous ideas of governance over prototypes. The example of Safecast shows how the ambiguity and liminality of prototyping strengthens rather than weakens the personal and social agency invested in similar open-source projects. The moment that shows the strength of this liminal and hybrid prototyping is when Safecast integrated a patented technology into its open-source kit. The company Solar Pocket Factory was a joint effort and network of MIT graduates from Haddock Invention, a company based in Hong Kong that operated in Shenzhen with a complex network of affiliates. The goal of the garage network was to produce disruptive, low-tech prototypes that provide solutions to developed and developing countries in terms of energy efficiency. The cells (garage networks) around prototypes were supposed to create ‘a global invention organism - the Ocean Invention Network’. The radical engagements with time and future over prototypes mobilize actors and forces without imposing any teleological goals but revealing new technological and political challenges.

530.text: This article explores the liminal experiences of prototyping and the paradoxes of the open hardware communitas in Shenzhen. It examines the MakerBot controversy and the successful open hardware projects that followed, as well as the transition from expiring patent to open source and back to new patented technology. It discusses the liminal activities of prototyping and the concept of Kairos in prototyping, which opens various futures in technology and governance. It also examines the agency and power of makers, hackers, and geeks through prototyping and material engagement in future-making. The article also looks at the demiurge paradox in Plato's views of governance and the importance of liminal environments for engaging and experimenting with different concepts of governance, infrastructure, politics, and future. Finally, it proposes the model of exploratory and public sandboxes for governance over prototypes.

531.text: This paper examines the concept of prototyping for governance, which is based on Plato's tripartite theory of the soul. It is argued that this theory is outdated and that the main goal of politics should be agency over time and the future. Prototyping for governance is seen as a liminal practice that enables transitions, transformations, and open-ended experiments between existing and new configurations of power, resources, subjectivities, fears, and fantasies. It is argued that prototypes should be seen as liminal and liminoid, fostering Kairos as agency in technology and governance. Prototypes are seen as messy, complex, and ambiguous objects that demarcate the limits and conditions of technology and governance. They are seen as open-ended and collaborative, enabling individuals and communities to decide what ‘small’ and ‘big’ futures and projects to build around the prototypes. It is argued that citizens should be seen as homo ludens, playful citizens who enjoy their free time and engage with others in vita activa. The liminal environments offer a model on how to design and govern without falling into the trap of teleological expectation about technology or society and preserve the future as open and public infrastructure.

532.text: Appius Claudius Caecus, the great Roman builder of roads and bridges, is known as the first homo faber. His last name literally means ‘blind’, implying the brute force he used to impose a technological change without political consensus or process. He is a policy maker that uses investment in infrastructure and innovation to transform society, but in the process misuses his power and corrupts political values. He is an example of Kairos, a man ‘fighting’ the capricious nature and chance in the universe with a design that promises technological progress. Francis Bacon was inspired by Appius Caecus and his project of Instauratio, which led to the excesses of the 20th century. The alternative to the solipsistic ‘creator of the world’ is the homo ludens, the fool and trickster that use science, technology, and society as playgrounds for idiosyncratic goals. Collectives like PechBlenda and Hackteria offer an alternative to the myth of Silicon Valley entrepreneurs, and remind us of the importance of remaining free to generate various metaphysical and cosmological ideas. 535.text: This paper explores the use of prototyping in governance, and how it can be used to restore the value of time as Kairos, an opportunity for innovation, discovery, and transformation. It discusses the dichotomies of agency and structure, politics and cosmology, and time as Kairos and Chronos, and how Chronos as a quantifiable, controllable, and predictable time of cycles and patterns in nature or other nonhuman phenomena defines the insights into cosmology or ontology that reduce politics to control and automation. It also discusses how prototypes manifest human ingenuity, agency, and the use of time as Kairos, but also enforce the rule of Chronos in society. To restore the value of time as Kairos, the paper revisits the early instrument making, as well as present prototyping in the hackerspaces, makerspaces, and citizen labs. It proposes a way to scale the experience of prototyping in liminal environments, or design policy process that supports Kairos and agency in technology and governance through the so-called "exploratory sandboxes". Finally, it discusses how prototypes can mediate the dichotomies of Theoretical and Practical Reason.

536.text: This article discusses the importance of public participation in prototyping and the dichotomy of episteme and techne, theoretical and practical reason. It argues that the values and future goals should be defined and negotiated, rather than predetermined. It proposes the use of prototypes to support agency over the future beyond the lure of monopoly, and suggests the use of public and exploratory sandboxes to highlight the function of metaphors in the history of computing. It explains how metaphors express imagination and agency in language and technology, and how the transformation of metaphors into algorithms plays a crucial role in the development of computing paradigms and contemporary ideals of algorithmic governance. It warns against the misuse of algorithms as metaphors for governance, which reduces all decisions to automation and threatens personal and collective agency. The article concludes by emphasizing the need for hybrid and liminal environments to experiment with metaphors and algorithms while preserving the differences between questions of governance and computing.

537.text: Metaphors and allegories have played an important role in the development of algorithms and network infrastructures since the late 1960s. Famous experiments such as the "Dining Philosophers", "Two Generals" and "Byzantine Generals" attacks or the "flows, catch/throw" metaphors have inspired generations of computer scientists to design new algorithms. Exploratory sandboxes extend this function of a good metaphor to issues of policy and governance, making the technical, social, and political commitments of stakeholders visible and enabling decisions and experiments that define common goals. Algorithms and infrastructures will never become solutions to a puzzle or means of teleology and cosmology, but embody a new way of understanding the relationship between technology and society that preserves the value of open futures and agency over time. The reversal of the relationship between a metaphor and an algorithm leads to a reduction in the level of governance to technology and a lack of new challenges for both algorithms and governance. 538.text: Metaphors of sharing resources or coordinating attacks influenced the design of early computers and networks, which paradoxically became ideals of governance as automation. Algorithms, which define computer networks and protocols, have become standard metaphors for governance, such as the automation of blockchain, artificial intelligence, and other "smart" technologies. Leslie Lamport's influential "Byzantine General Problem" in 1982, pretended to refer to a real historical occurrence and reversed the relationship between algorithms and metaphors, reducing the challenges of governance to a problem of automation. Lamport's later metaphor of a parliament on the Greek island of Paxos, blurred the difference between metaphors and algorithms, historical processes, and abstractions. The Bitcoin protocol has claimed that algorithmic governance is a superior form of governance and is a metaphor for a novel form of governance such as automation and decentralization. The original blockchain algorithm is a pamphlet for a new form of automated governance that completely eliminates the divisions between metaphor, allegory, and technology. The idea of governance as an algorithmic and technological ‘fix’ to social and political problems leads to arbitrary precedents that create power imbalances with unintended consequences.

539.text: This article discusses the problem of the reduction of governance to automation, which closes both the future of governance and technology, including the development of new algorithms or reflection and critique leading to a better society. It proposes the use of sandboxes as a way to involve citizens in the entire cycle of innovation and governance, from prototyping to implementation and regulation. Regulatory sandboxes, which help stakeholders negotiate future services and regulations in a safe, controlled, and temporary environment outside of the market or society, rarely engage the public. Exploratory sandboxes are proposed as an alternative to the normative ideals of politics as something driven by theoretical reason, insights, and (good) intentions. They balance the promises of blockchain applications and services, such as bitcoin cryptocurrency, self-regulating and anonymous DAOs (Decentralized Autonomous Organizations) or smart contracts, while allowing participants to test and iterate how they will work in practice without making final decisions. The Lithopy project was designed as a pilot of an exploratory and public sandbox to reclaim citizens' agency over the future.

540.text: Regulatory sandboxes are a hybrid model of governance and development that connect the work on regulations and code while avoiding the paradoxes of blockchain governance or the extreme promises of ‘governance by design’. Exploratory sandboxes extend the concept of a testing environment commonly used in software development and computer security to the regulation and governance of emerging services. They explore the interaction between emerging technology and society, regulations, and code, to anticipate potential problems and respond to them. The main purpose of a regulatory sandbox is to mitigate risks and share the risks between different stakeholders, to anticipate challenges and support adoption without disruption or uncertainty. The main difference between the exploratory and regulatory sandbox remains the question of visibility of the four forces shaping the future services and their interactions. The exploratory sandbox invites all direct and indirect stakeholders to be part of the decision-making process and supports their understanding of regulation and technology. The Lithopy project was designed as an exploratory sandbox for emerging blockchain services that uses satellite data to automate smart contracts related to becoming a citizen or owning a property. It placed the workshop participants in an imaginary ‘smart village’ with functional prototypes of smart contracts, templates, and guided the participants through decision making on a common future as an imaginary community. 541.text: Lithopy is a near-future simulation that explores the anticipatory governance of future blockchain infrastructures. During the workshops in 2019 and 2020, it became a sandbox that emphasized the participation of stakeholders in smart contracts. The village existed as a simulated ledger on a server (testnet) that the participants inhabited over 2- to 4-hour workshops. During the modification of the code for the testnet, the participants made decisions on the type of regulations of the future services by voting and deliberating. In 2020, Lithopy was redesigned to become a ‘contact language’ or ‘trade zone’ for programming and regulation through natural language. The experience with extreme forms of surveillance and automated governance over satellite and drone data in Lithopy triggered the discussions that led to voting and decision-making processes in the workshops. The sandbox model offered an ideal environment for designing and deciding together upon the future by combining different tools (natural language, regulations, and code) without prioritizing any regulatory force or domain. Exploratory sandboxes support the future as something collectively negotiated, experienced, and prototyped, rather than imposed via a teleology of progress and restoration. 542.text: Sandbox environments offer an alternative to embedding predefined cultural, social, and legal norms into design specifications or machine-readable code. The Lithopy sandbox experiment revealed that most participants preferred to regulate code through audits and industry standards rather than government intervention or free market mechanisms. Sandboxes balance calls for innovation, disruption, and technological change with participation, deliberation, and legitimacy. They address the structural challenges of algorithmic governance and automation by connecting deliberation with experiments that work simultaneously on regulations and code. The purpose of a hybrid public sandbox is to support experimental forms of algorithmic citizenship and to create new forms of division of power. The main problem in current attempts to combine regulations and code is their democratic deficit and ahistorical narrative. Algorithmic governance is a necessary consequence of the Leviathan metaphor, which is a technical apparatus that demands unconditional obedience. It is the embodiment of our ideal of absolute control over the future and time over some instrument, knowledge, and mechanism. Algorithmic 'Leviathans' outsource citizen agency and sovereignty to superhuman institutions, platforms, and protocols that promise peace, stability, health, and efficiency as the only goals of the modern algorithmic state. 543.text: In this book, the paradox of rational beings agreeing on an irrational and absolute control to be the only alternative to lawlessness is explored. This control is enforced by algorithmic sovereignty over emerging infrastructures such as blockchain or ML technologies. The critique of the Leviathan as a reinforcement of an old pagan ritual of human sacrifices is discussed, as well as John Locke's description of absolute sovereignty as a catastrophic lack of judgment and governance. Schmitt's analysis of the Leviathan leads to the present algorithmic governance, which is an artificial system with absolute authority over citizens who trade their sovereignty and natural rights for security. An alternative to this absolute victory is proposed in the form of sandboxes, which are zoos for dangerous algorithms. These sandboxes enable citizens to gradually domesticate algorithms and participate in the automation process. The Lithopy sandbox is an example of this, which supports tactical and participatory automation and preserves social and personal agency in algorithm design processes.

544.text: Prototypes in society mediate the different expectations and experiences of time and agency over the future. On the one hand, they support the open-ended exploration and flourishing of human agency. On the other hand, they promise innovation as control over the future and governance. Examples of ancient clocks, Renaissance visions of scientific instruments, and infrastructures for automation close the future to predetermined goals of progress and theological restoration. Prototyping is an opportunity for agency, vision, and experiments beyond any universal solution and absolute rule. It is a matter of participation and empowerment, and a need for democratizing future-making and realizing that time is Kairos, a public resource and infrastructure for commons preserving the opportunity for our agency. Science and technology as mundane, accessible, and everyday practice resist the myth of automation as an ideal for governance. Governance over prototypes is an attempt to rethink the engagement with science and technology beyond the promises and myths of automation that lead to teleological fantasies of absolute control and destruction. Exploratory sandboxes support the participation of citizens in the whole process of designing and deciding on the future ‘Leviathans’. 545.text: In 2008, Rudolf Mrázek, an eminent historian of science and technology and an expert on Indonesia, made a casual remark to the author that Indonesia would profoundly change their views on philosophy, science, and technology. This remark made no sense to the author at the time, but after moving to Yogyakarta, Indonesia, they experienced a unique form of prototyping that combined research with community activism, hacktivism, artistic sensibility, and visions. This experience changed their view of the role of science and technology in society, and made them realize that patented science and the rat race in journal publications and other rankings make little sense. Through interactions with various collectives around the world, the author was inspired to imagine a future of science, technology, and society that supports personal and social action beyond any teleology of progress, exaggerated expectations of startup culture, or final and idealized goals. Prototyping in informal networks of geeks, makers, and hackers around the world rarely results in a finished product, but instead serves to engage over new technologies and ideas, bridge cultural and geopolitical divisions, and emphasize the unique experience of time as Kairos.
