547.text: This article examines the desirability of the Regulatory Sandbox as an appropriate mechanism for regulating Fintech in China. It looks at the concept of Regulatory Sandboxes, which are regulatory frameworks that allow firms to test innovative products, services, and business models in a controlled environment. It also examines the concept of Constitutional Government, as well as the use of metaphors in computer networking terminology. Additionally, it looks at the legal landscape of Blockchain and other Distributed Ledger Technologies, the ethics of algorithms, and the potential of Blockchain for commons governance. It also examines the concept of Experimentalist Governance, the dangers of faulty, biased, or malicious algorithms, and the use of Smart Contracts. Finally, it looks at the concept of Cryptocurrency and Governance, as well as the use of Artificial Intelligence in the public sector.

548.text: The Myth of Automation from Sundial to Blockchain: Governance over Rituals, Machines, and Prototypes is a discussion of the fantasy of automation and control over time and the future. It examines the metaphysical, political, and material conditions under which governance becomes a matter of automation and algorithms. It proposes exploratory sandboxes that extend the practices identified in the forgotten history of instrument making and observed in the liminal spaces, increasing participation and redefining representation. It looks at the origins of the myth of automation, which can be traced back to the 6th century B.C.E. and the anecdotes about Thales of Miletus, connecting his knowledge of astronomical cycles and time as Chronos to his free time, which is interpreted as Kairos. It suggests that citizens should be participants and stakeholders in their future, rather than mere users of future infrastructures, and proposes prototyping governance as a way to reclaim control over the future and time. It emphasizes personal and social action through prototyping that supports Kairos in technology and governance, and encourages agonistic, plural, and open futures.

549.text: This article examines the dichotomy of Chronos and Kairos, which expresses a tension between natural systems and political projects. Chronos is the essence of automation and algorithmic rule, while Kairos is time as an opportunity for action and decision-making. Prototyping is a practice that liberates the future and time for personal and social action, and it has served various pragmatic, didactic, and even emancipatory purposes throughout history. Renaissance artisans, such as Cornelius Drebbel, explore future(s) beyond the teleological promises of Instauratio, and their playful engagements with prototypes of new instruments are open-ended and equally concerned with transformation and Kairos in science, technology, and society (governance). Bacon's academy of science serves the project of Instauratio and fulfills God's promise to humanity, while Drebbel's folly of empiricism and Bornitz's transgender body politics use instruments and prototypes to perform the future as open to engagement and radical visions. 550.text: Prototyping is an important political action as well as a technological one, as demonstrated by self-governance experiments. It is a way to preserve agency and Kairos in governance, emphasizing participation and empowerment. Barbara Cassin's two concepts of time in ancient Greek philosophy inspired the view of prototyping as the expression of Kairos in technology and governance. Hackerspaces and makerspaces are creative, yet often failed explorations of the skills of hackers, forming communities around tools and open-source projects that are expressions of resistance and exploration of different (mis)uses. These prototypes are autotelic and participatory, supporting artists, philosophers, and other unexpected ‘users’. Examples of projects include transforming a common Indonesian mobile food truck into a scientific laboratory, connecting science to everyday life practice, and exploring the media archeology of etching. Prototyping for governance enables citizens to gain agency and disperse the asymmetries of power, actively defining their future by connecting prototyping with governance. It is an agonistic ideal of future making as a matter of Kairos that serves open, even conflicting, political ends that are crucial for preserving the agency, plurality, and freedom of the political life.

551.text: This paper explores the concept of Kairos in governance and technology, which is an open future that is open to change and transformation without any final goals. It uses the example of the Special Economic Zone (SEZ) in Shenzhen, China, which was a mythical place of innovation and hacker dreams between 2012 and 2015. It examines the liminal experiences of prototyping and the paradoxes of the open hardware communitas in Shenzhen, including the MakerBot controversy, the successful open hardware projects that followed, and the transition from expiring patent to open source and back to new patented technology. It discusses the liminal activities of prototyping and the concept of Kairos in prototyping, which opens various futures in technology and governance. It also examines the agency and power of makers, hackers, and geeks through prototyping and material engagement in future-making.
